diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms, including acute pericarditis, skin rashes, kidney involvement (proteinuria), and joint inflammation (synovitis). Neurological manifestations can include seizures.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for causing joint inflammation and damage, can also involve other organs. Rarely, it can lead to pericarditis, and skin manifestations can occasionally mimic psoriasis. It can cause secondary amyloidosis leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, presenting with synovitis. It can occasionally cause proteinuria due to kidney involvement and, in rare cases, involve the heart or possibly lead to neurological manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: An overlap syndrome that can present symptoms similar to lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including acute pericarditis, proteinuria from kidney involvement, rash, and synovitis. Neurological involvement can sometimes lead to seizures.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects salivary and lacrimal glands but can have extraglandular manifestations including joint symptoms (synovitis), kidney involvement (proteinuria), and rare nervous system involvement potentially leading to seizures.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare multisystem inflammatory disorder that can cause skin rashes, arthritis (synovitis), and neurological symptoms (including seizures). While pericarditis and proteinuria are less common, they can occur.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Can involve multiple organ systems, presenting with skin rashes, joint inflammation, and potentially heart involvement such as pericarditis. Kidney involvement can lead to proteinuria, and neurological involvement may result in seizures.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory condition primarily affecting skin and muscles but can have systemic features. Rash and synovitis are common, and in severe cases, it can affect the heart (pericarditis) and rarely involve the kidneys or central nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis (e.g., ANCA-associated vasculitis)
diagnoses.rationale: A group of diseases causing inflammation of blood vessels, which can lead to a variety of symptoms, including but not limited to skin manifestations, joint pain, kidney involvement (proteinuria), and, less commonly, seizures.

diagnoses.name: Infectious (e.g., Endocarditis, Viral infections)
diagnoses.rationale: Certain infections can lead to a wide array of symptoms including acute pericarditis, rashes, joint inflammation, kidney damage (proteinuria), and neurological symptoms like seizures, depending on the pathogen.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (such as Epstein-Barr Virus, HIV)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Laryngitis
diagnoses.description: Long-term inflammation of the larynx which may be related to multiple causes including chronic use, infection, and other irritants. Chronic inflammation could manifest alongside systemic conditions like depression or could result from chronic irritation as seen in leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Leukoplakia
diagnoses.description: A condition which causes white patches inside the mouth and on the tongue can be associated with chronic irritation, including that of prolonged laryngitis or reflux, which may also affect the larynx.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood, leading to overproduction of white cells, including basophils. This may be associated indirectly with symptoms like fatigue, which could contribute to a diagnosis of depression.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by an underactive thyroid gland, might cause symptoms that either mimic or exacerbate depression. It has been linked with menstrual and fertility issues, potentially aggravating endometriosis.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges could correlate with endometriosis in terms of menstruation related symptoms. It can also have mood-related symptoms that may be confused with or contribute to depression.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue may worsen with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. This could encapsulate the general low mood or diagnosed depression.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.description: Such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) which can have diverse symptoms, including those affecting mood (depression), various blood abnormalities (including potentially basophilia), and could be linked with chronic inflammatory conditions like endometriosis.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can cause symptoms that resemble depression or worsen existing depression, affects blood production possibly leading to basophilia, and may indirectly affect mucosal health, potentially aggravating conditions like leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: While primarily associated with anemia, the condition can have wide-ranging symptoms including fatigue and depression, and in severe cases, it can affect mucosal health and potentially relate to leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Endometrial Cancer
diagnoses.description: While primarily a diagnosis for patients presenting symptoms aligned with endometriosis, it can have broader systemic impacts. There's no direct link to basophilia or laryngitis, but cancer's systemic effects can potentially manifest a wide range of symptoms including mood changes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Conditions
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as autoimmune disorders can cause lymphadenitis, headaches, and episodic weakness due to chronic inflammation affecting various parts of the body. Elevated immunoglobulins often indicate an active immune response.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A disorder where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to weight gain, episodic weakness, and can contribute to immune system irregularities.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease affecting multiple organs in the body, including the lymph nodes and central nervous system, which can cause lymphadenitis and headaches. Weight gain might be indirect, related to reduced activity due to weakness and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, which can cause lymphadenitis and systemic symptoms like weight gain (from fluid retention), headache, episodic weakness, and might affect immunoglobulin production due to immune system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complicated disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Symptoms often include headaches, weakness, and immune system abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of the plasma cells in bone marrow, associated with high levels of immunoglobulins, which can cause bone pain and episodic weakness. Lymphadenitis and weight gain are less direct but possible through various complications.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when your body makes too much of the hormone cortisol over a long period. Symptoms include weight gain, weakened immune response, and can potentially lead to episodic weakness.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the immune system produces too many lymphocytes, leading to lymphadenitis. It can also cause an increase in certain types of immunoglobulins, fatigue, and potential weight gain due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The virus and its advanced stage, AIDS, can cause lymphadenitis, headache, episodic weakness, and can be associated with an increase in certain immunoglobulins as the immune system becomes progressively compromised.

diagnoses.name: Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)
diagnoses.description: Associated with Kaposi sarcoma and certain lymphoproliferative diseases. It can cause lymphadenopathy, affect the immune system leading to abnormal immunoglobulin levels, and contribute to various systemic symptoms including episodic weakness.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by persistent and excessive worry about a number of different things, which might contribute to physical symptoms like folliculitis (due to stress-related behaviors), cognitive dysfunction, congestion, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A common but serious mood disorder that affects how you feel, think, and handle daily activities, which can lead to various physical symptoms including cognitive dysfunction and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress
diagnoses.description: A state of ongoing physiological arousal that occurs when a person perceives that the demands placed on them exceed their ability to cope, which may manifest in symptoms such as folliculitis, anxiety, congestion, cognitive dysfunction, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms. It might contribute to the congestion observed, and exacerbate states of anxiety or irritability.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. It can cause symptoms like fatigue, cognitive dysfunction, and mood swings (such as irritability and anxiety).

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts. It is associated with symptoms such as anxiety, depression, and could potentially lead to skin issues like folliculitis due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that disrupt the quality of sleep, such as insomnia, can lead to cognitive dysfunction, anxiety, irritability, and indirectly to skin conditions due to poor immune function.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition of the skin (eczema) that can lead to or worsen folliculitis, and possibly impact mental health, contributing to symptoms such as anxiety and cognitive dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases where the body's immune system attacks healthy cells, potentially explaining the combination of symptoms. For example, lupus can lead to cognitive dysfunction, skin issues (folliculitis-like symptoms), and mood changes.

diagnoses.name: Substance Abuse
diagnoses.description: The overindulgence in or dependence on an addictive substance, especially alcohol or drugs, can lead to a variety of physical and mental health issues, including those listed.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, increasing the risk of infections like pneumonia, and can also cause lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Poorly controlled diabetes can lead to dyslipidemia, increase susceptibility to infections, and in some cases, contribute to lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease can lead to dyslipidemia and increase the risk of infections due to a weakened immune system.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and immune system abnormalities, leading to increased infections, lymphadenopathy, and dyslipidemia in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis involves granuloma formation in various organs, including the lymph nodes, leading to lymphadenopathy, and can affect the lungs, increasing pneumonia risk.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenopathy and increasing susceptibility to infections due to immune system compromise.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic lung disease that can increase the risk of pneumonia and is associated with frequent waking due to respiratory distress.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders that impair the immune system, increasing susceptibility to infections and potentially leading to frequent cases of pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can also cause lymphadenopathy and increase the risk of pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause systemic symptoms such as dyslipidemia and lymphadenopathy, and increases susceptibility to infection due to both the disease and the medications used for treatment.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body, potentially causing symptoms like onychodystrophy (nail dystrophy) and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Long-standing disease of the kidneys leading to renal failure. Symptoms can include pallor due to anemia, hearing loss, and possibly edema, though tinnitus is less common.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition that can also affect the nails (onychodystrophy) and joints, and has been associated with an increased risk of autoimmune disorders.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones, can lead to hearing loss, pallor, and onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including hearing loss, angioedema, and onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: A rare disease that occurs when a substance called amyloid builds up in your organs, can cause hearing loss, and onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). It doesn't typically cause onychodystrophy but is closely related to the symptom of angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause a range of symptoms including pallor, hearing loss, and in severe cases, skin changes that may affect nail health.

diagnoses.name: Relapsing Polychondritis
diagnoses.description: A multi-systemic condition characterized by recurrent episodes of inflammation of cartilage and other tissues throughout the body, can lead to hearing loss and other symptoms although onychodystrophy is less common.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that can cause pallor and hearing loss; it's less directly linked to onychodystrophy, tinnitus, or angioedema but can have overlapping symptoms in the context of broader nutritional deficiencies.

diagnoses: Osteopenia/Osteoporosis Secondary to a Chronic Condition
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: CVID (Common Variable Immune Deficiency) with associated autoimmunity

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing symptoms like malabsorption and can lead to hemorrhoids due to nutritional deficiencies.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common anemia that occurs when the body doesn't have enough iron, leading to symptoms like hemorrhoids due to increased straining and can contribute to word-finding difficulties due to cognitive effects.

diagnoses.name: Crohn’s Disease
diagnoses.description: A type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can cause malabsorption, leading to various nutritional deficiencies that could manifest as hemorrhoids, and cognitive issues such as word-finding difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that can cause warts on various parts of the body, including the genital area. It has potential links to periodontal disease through oral manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to malabsorption and can contribute to cognitive issues like word-finding difficulty.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood glucose, commonly associated with periodontal disease due to blood vessel changes and can contribute to malabsorption and skin conditions like warts.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition can result from malabsorption and lead to anemia and cognitive changes, including word-finding difficulties. It could also indirectly contribute to conditions like hemorrhoids through anemia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome can cause a wide range of symptoms including warts due to viral infections, malabsorption, periodontal disease, and cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation and can present multiple symptoms including hemorrhoids and could potentially contribute to cognitive issues and malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: A general term for diseases that cause inflammation in the intestines, such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, leading to malabsorption and can contribute to conditions such as hemorrhoids.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Conjunctivitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the conjunctiva of the eye due to an allergic reaction causing irritated eyes and can sometimes affect vision.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Conjunctivitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the eye's conjunctiva usually causing redness, irritation, and discharge.

diagnoses.name: Viral Conjunctivitis
diagnoses.description: A viral infection of the eye's conjunctiva often associated with a respiratory tract infection, causing eye irritation and possible visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition, causing difficulty concentrating and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: An anxiety disorder characterized by chronic and exaggerated worry and tension, often with no apparent reason, leading to concentration difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which there is a deficiency of red cells or of haemoglobin in the blood, resulting in pallor and weariness, potentially affecting concentration and causing visual symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: An overactive thyroid gland releasing too much thyroid hormone, which can cause difficulty focusing, both visually and mentally.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune condition involving the central nervous system, impairing everything from physical mobility to vision and cognitive functions.

diagnoses.name: Dry Eye Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a lack of adequate tears to lubricate and nourish the eye, leading to eye irritation and difficulty focusing visually.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body (cross-reactivity), potentially causing various symptoms including eye complications and cognitive difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
reasoning: Dysosmia and urinary tract infection are more common in individuals with diabetes due to fluctuating blood glucose levels affecting bodily systems.
Mood lability can also be associated with the psychological impact or as a manifestation of poorly controlled diabetes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
reasoning: Urinary tract infections and changes in urinary output can be indicative of underlying kidney issues.
Mood lability can be related to the overall impact on health and well-being.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., Lupus)
reasoning: Can present with a wide range of symptoms affecting multiple body systems including skin (folliculitis), urinary system (UTIs), and respiratory system (bronchitis).
Mood lability may be related to both the psychological impact of living with a chronic illness and the direct impact of autoimmune inflammation on the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
reasoning: Immunocompromised individuals are more susceptible to infections such as UTIs and bronchitis.
Folliculitis is also more common in people with weakened immune systems.
Mood lability can be associated with both the psychological aspects of managing a chronic disease and possible direct effects of HIV on the brain.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
reasoning: Bronchitis could be a symptom indicating COPD, especially if recurrent or chronic.
UTIs can occur more frequently in individuals with chronic diseases due to overall weakened state and potential for hospital-acquired infections.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
reasoning: Although more specific to females, it can present with mood lability due to hormonal imbalances.
Patients with PCOS are at an increased risk for type 2 diabetes, which could indirectly increase the risk for UTIs.

diagnoses.name: Depression
reasoning: While primarily a psychiatric diagnosis, depression can have significant physical manifestations, including psychosomatic symptoms or neglect of personal hygiene leading to conditions like folliculitis.
Mood lability is a key feature of depression.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
reasoning: Similar to depression, anxiety can manifest with physical symptoms or behaviors that may exacerbate conditions like UTIs (through neglect of health) or bronchitis.
Mood lability can also be prominent in anxiety disorders.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
reasoning: Can contribute to mood lability and may indirectly influence the severity or frequency of infections due to impacts on the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
reasoning: Mood lability is common due to hormonal imbalances.
Increased risk of infections, including UTIs and skin infections like folliculitis, due to the immunosuppressive effect of cortisol.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.explanation: Certain viral infections can cause symptoms such as chest pain (due to myocarditis or pericarditis), and can also lead to neurological symptoms like seizures. While less directly associated, immune reactions could potentially link to dysmenorrhea or otitis media.

Specific bacterial infections could cause otitis media and potentially exacerbate underlying conditions that lead to chest pain (like pericarditis). Secondary effects could potentially influence seizure occurrences or immune responses leading to monocytosis.

Certain inflammatory disorders can cause a wide array of symptoms, including chest pain (from inflammation of heart or lung tissues), seizures (from neuroinflammation), and could potentially influence menstrual pain or lead to ear infections.

Autoimmune conditions can lead to systemic inflammation affecting various organs and systems. This can result in symptoms such as chest pain (lupus affecting the heart or lungs), seizures (neurological involvement), and possibly monocytosis as part of the immune response.

Inflammation of the heart muscle, which could potentially explain the chest pain. While more indirectly linked, systemic illness with myocarditis can lead to broader symptomatology, including potential effects on immune function.
Inflammation of the pericardium often presents with chest pain and could be part of a broader inflammatory or infectious process affecting the body, thereby possibly influencing other symptoms.

Primary seizure disorders could account for the seizures. While not directly causing other symptoms like chest pain or otitis media, systemic stress from seizures might exacerbate underlying conditions or immune responses.

Conditions like Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome can have wide-reaching symptoms including chest pain (due to vascular or internal organ involvement), and potentially influence the frequency of infections (like otitis media) or immune system behavior.

An explanation for dysmenorrhea, and while it wouldn't directly cause seizures or otitis media, complicated cases can have systemic effects. Chest pain can be experienced in rare thoracic endometriosis.

Stress and psychological factors can manifest physically, potentially exacerbating or mimicking symptoms like chest pain, seizures (non-epileptic seizures), and even influencing menstrual pain or the immune system's behavior (potentially relating to monocytosis).

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with eosinophilia
Acute and chronic infections causing eosinophilia (e.g., fungal, bacterial)

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, and can cause complications such as easy bleeding and enlarged spleen which might affect appetite.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can lead to decreased appetite due to systemic symptoms and may also cause easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of the lymphatic system that can lead to lymphadenitis, decreased appetite, and, in some cases, can be associated with paraneoplastic syndromes that lead to polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma that can cause lymphadenitis, and symptoms such as decreased appetite. It can be associated with systemic symptoms including those related to the blood that could potentially link to polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: A disorder that can cause easy bleeding due to a decrease in platelets, which are necessary for clotting. It is less commonly associated with the other symptoms but could present with nonspecific systemic symptoms like decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: An iron disorder in which the body simply loads too much iron. This condition, over time, can lead to complications such as cirrhosis, which can cause decreased appetite and could indirectly relate to conditions affecting blood cell production and function.

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare bone marrow cancer that disrupts the body's normal production of blood cells. It can cause symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and decreased appetite due to an enlarged spleen. Polycythemia can occur in the early stages of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that progresses slowly. CLL can cause swollen lymph nodes and other systemic symptoms like decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that can lead to the overproduction of platelets, potentially resulting in easy bleeding or clotting disorders. Linked to a risk of developing polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the blood, which can result in symptoms related to polycythemia and easy bleeding. Dyslipidemia is also a concern in SLE management.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Cushing's syndrome can manifest through symptoms such as hypoglycemia, striae (stretch marks), and physical sensitivities due to cortisol excess. Cysts may also appear in various organs, including the ovaries, due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reasoning: PCOS often presents with cysts on the ovaries, can indirectly cause hypoglycemia through insulin resistance, and may also lead to striae due to rapid changes in weight. Sleep disturbances and physical sensitivities can be associated symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia
diagnoses.reasoning: This genetic disorder can cause symptoms like hypoglycemia and physical sensitivities due to hormone imbalance. While striae and frequent waking are not classic symptoms, hormonal imbalances may contribute to their presence.

diagnoses.name: Insulinoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Insulinoma, a tumor of the pancreas that secretes insulin, can cause hypoglycemia. While cysts, striae, frequent waking, and physical sensitivities are not direct symptoms, the hypoglycemia it causes can lead to a broader range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal Cortex Carcinoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Adrenal cortex carcinoma may produce hormones leading to symptoms such as hypoglycemia and striae. Cysts and physical sensitivities may be a direct result of the tumor's growth and metabolic effects.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Hypothyroidism can indirectly lead to hypoglycemia and may manifest with frequent waking and sensitivities due to hormonal imbalance. Cysts, notably in the form of ovarian cysts, can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition, characterized by insufficient production of cortisol and aldosterone, can lead to hypoglycemia and increased skin sensitivity. While striae and frequent waking are more commonly associated with its counterpart, Cushing's syndrome, they can appear due to treatment or as part of an overall endocrine disorder.

diagnoses.name: Ectopic ACTH Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This is a condition where ACTH, a hormone that stimulates cortisol production, is produced outside the pituitary gland, often by a tumor, leading to symptoms similar to those of Cushing's syndrome, including hypoglycemia, striae, and potentially cysts due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Lipoid Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia
diagnoses.reasoning: An extremely rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia that can lead to symptoms like hypoglycemia and potentially cause features like striae and sensitivities due to severe disruption in steroidogenesis.

diagnoses.name: Acromegaly
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily associated with excessive growth hormone leading to enlarged features, acromegaly can indirectly affect blood sugar regulation, leading to hypoglycemia, and contribute to skin changes such as striae. Sleep disturbances are common due to the condition’s physical manifestations.

diagnoses: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria (for angioedema without a clear cause)
Blepharospasm may be a primary condition or a symptom in conditions like Parkinson’s disease and Tourette syndrome
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction (with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms - DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur suddenly and affect the whole body.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing sudden swelling beneath the skin, potentially triggering severe abdominal cramps and airway obstruction.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by the accumulation of mast cells in the body's tissues which can lead to symptoms like skin lesions, abdominal discomfort, and anaphylactoid reactions.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food, causing various symptoms including abdominal pain, angioedema, and syncope.

diagnoses.name: Medication Allergy
diagnoses.description: A adverse reaction of the immune system to certain medications, which can manifest in symptoms such as angioedema, pruritus, and gastrointestinal distress.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, and brain, potentially leading to a wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A syndrome caused by a carcinoid tumor that secretes serotonin or other chemicals into the bloodstream, leading to flushing, abdominal cramps, and in severe cases, heart damage.

diagnoses.name: Alpha-gal Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to alpha-gal sugars found in red meat and products made from mammals, which can cause anaphylaxis, gastrointestinal upset, and skin reactions hours after consumption.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain bacterial infections, often associated with tampon use, surgery, and skin wounds, characterized by sudden fever, rash, hypotension, and multi-organ involvement.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting that occurs in response to a trigger, such as stress or pain, leading to a sudden decrease in heart rate and blood pressure, which reduces blood flow to the brain.

diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) exacerbation with secondary symptoms
Urinary Tract Infection (UTI) with systemic symptoms
Common Cold or Upper Respiratory Infection (URI) with systemic involvement
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD, with acute exacerbation)
Ototoxicity (e.g., from aminoglycosides, NSAIDs, or chemotherapy agents)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A subtype of migraine that involves visual disturbances (scintillation) and other neurological symptoms before the headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by a constant ache or pressure around the head, especially at the temples or back of the head and neck.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headache
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes intense headaches on one side of the head, typically around the eye, and can be accompanied by symptoms like redness of the eye, drooping eyelids, and nasal congestion.

diagnoses.name: Medication Overuse Headache
diagnoses.description: Headaches that occur from the overuse of headache medications. It's often a dull, persistent headache that worsens in the morning.

diagnoses.name: Brain Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain can cause severe headaches, vision problems, and other symptoms if it ruptures.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, causing brain cells to die. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, and difficulty with vision.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, and neck stiffness.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure, which can cause headaches and other symptoms if it reaches a severe level known as hypertensive crisis.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, often in the head, that can cause severe headaches, vision problems, and scalp tenderness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by diarrhea, cramps, nausea, vomiting, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Food poisoning
diagnoses.description: Illness caused by eating contaminated food. It's frequently characterized by nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Viral Menigitis
diagnoses.description: An infection causing the inflammation of the brain's and spinal cord's protective membranes, presenting with fever, headache, vomiting, or weakness.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when the loss of body fluids, mostly water, exceeds the amount that is taken in, with symptoms like weakness, headache, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain, might cause vomiting, headache, weakness, and other symptoms depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Concussion
diagnoses.description: A brain injury caused by a blow to the head or a sudden jolt, often leading to headache, nausea, vomiting, and photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Hangover
diagnoses.description: A series of unpleasant psychological and physiological effects following heavy consumption of alcoholic beverages, including headache, nausea, light sensitivity, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Pregnancy
diagnoses.description: Early stages of pregnancy may cause morning sickness, which includes nausea and vomiting, along with headache and general malaise.

diagnoses.name: COVID-19
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, leading to symptoms like headache, weakness, and at times nausea or vomiting.

diagnoses: Vitamin and Mineral Deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin B12, Iron, Zinc)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of various parts of the body. It can manifest with skin, joint, renal, nervous system involvement, among others. Hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, oral ulcers, and nonscarring alopecia are common manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder which may present with features of lupus, scleroderma, polymyositis, including problems such as thrombocytopenia, hemolytic anemia, and oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, and in some cases, immune-mediated neutropenia.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity in the presence of persistently positive antiphospholipid antibodies. Some presentations may overlap with findings such as thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In severe cases, it can affect the skin, eyes, lungs, heart, and blood vessels, potentially leading to anemia and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce saliva and tears. It may also affect other parts of the body, including the skin and blood, potentially leading to hematological abnormalities and oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders characterized by inflammation of blood vessels, which can cause a range of symptoms depending on the organs affected. Hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia can be part of its presentation.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, including the brain. Symptoms may include mouth sores, eye inflammation, skin rashes and lesions, and more.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: A disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding, resulting from unusually low levels of platelets — the cells that help blood clot.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
diagnoses.description: A rare, acquired, life-threatening disease of the blood characterized by destruction of red blood cells, blood clots, and impaired bone marrow function.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Epilepsy (Secondary to CNS involvement in systemic disease)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., microscopic polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, hepatitis B/C, syphilis)
Panniculitis Associated With Connective Tissue Diseases
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if not directly related to the primary disease)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., HIV, Tuberculosis, depending on other specific signs and risk factors)
Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Infectious diseases (e.g., viral, bacterial, or tuberculous myelitis)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's Syndrome
